text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 35B44 35K57 35K20 35B09 blow-up point serial article Guo, Jong-Shenq; Lin, Chang-Shou; Shimojo, Masahiko Number: 1254.35029 Blow-up for a reaction-diffusion equation with variable coefficient. 2013 Summary: We study the blow-up behavior for positive solutions of a reaction-diffusion equation with nonnegative variable coefficient. When there is no stationary solution, we show that the solution blows up in finite time. Under certain conditions, we then show that any point with zero source cannot be a blow-up point.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 05C75 90C35 spanning cactus; computational complexity; approximation algorithms; cactus extension; odd spanning tree; even spanning tree serial article Kabadi, Santosh N.; Punnen, Abraham P. Number: 6109941 Spanning cactus of a graph: Existence, extension, optimization, and approximation. 2013 Summary: We show that testing if an undirected graph contains a bridgeless spanning cactus is NP-hard. As a consequence, the minimum spanning cactus problem (MSCP) on an undirected graph with 0-1 edge weights is NP-hard. For any subgraph math1 of math2 , we give polynomially testable necessary and sufficient conditions for math3 to be extendable to a cactus in math4 and the weighted version of this problem is shown to be NP-hard. A spanning tree is shown to be extendable to a cactus in math5 if and only if it has at least one node of even degree. When math6 is a spanning tree, we show that the weighted version can also be solved in polynomial time. Further, we give an math7 algorithm for computing a minimum cost spanning tree with at least one vertex of even degree on a graph on n nodes. Finally, we show that for a complete graph with edge-costs satisfying the triangle inequality, the MSCP is equivalent to a general class of optimization problems that properly includes the traveling salesman problem and they all have the same approximation hardness.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 05C78 05C10 05C60 serial article Drmota, Michael Number: 6106900 Embedded trees and the support of the ISE. 2013 Summary: Embedded trees are labelled rooted trees, where the root has zero label and where the labels of adjacent vertices differ (at most) by math1 . Recently it has been proved (see Chassaing and Schaeffer (2004) [8] and Janson and Marckert (2005) [11]) that the distribution of the maximum and minimum labels are closely related to the support of the density of the integrated superbrownian excursion (ISE). The purpose of this paper is to make this probabilistic limiting relation more explicit by using a generating function approach due to Bouttier et al. (2003) [6] that is based on properties of Jacobi‚Äôs math2 -functions. In particular, we derive an integral representation of the joint distribution function of the supremum and infimum of the support of the ISE in terms of the Weierstrass math3 -function. Furthermore we re-derive the limiting radius distribution in random quadrangulations (by Chassaing and Schaeffer (2004) [8]) with the help of exact counting generating functions.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 90C27 62K maximum coverage; optimal design of experiments; Kiefer‚Äôs math1 -criterion; polynomial-time approximability; rounding algorithms; submodularity; matrix inequalities serial article Sagnol, Guillaume Number: 6109948 Approximation of a maximum-submodular-coverage problem involving spectral functions, with application to experimental designs. 2013 Summary: We study a family of combinatorial optimization problems defined by a parameter math2 , which involves spectral functions applied to positive semidefinite matrices, and has some application in the theory of optimal experimental design. This family of problems tends to a generalization of the classical maximum coverage problem as math3 goes to 0, and to a trivial instance of the knapsack problem as math4 goes to 1.In this article, we establish a matrix inequality which shows that the objective function is submodular for all math5 , from which it follows that the greedy approach, which has often been used for this problem, always gives a design within math6 of the optimum. We next study the design found by rounding the solution of the continuous relaxed problem, an approach which has been applied by several authors. We prove an inequality which generalizes a classical result from the theory of optimal designs, and allows us to give a rounding procedure with an approximation factor which tends to 1 as math7 goes to 1.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 35J92 35D30 35B38 math1 -Laplacian; compactness condition; linking; crossing of eigenvalues serial article Yuan, Jian-Jun; Ou, Zeng-Qi Number: 6109983 Existence of solutions for a Dirichlet problem with a math2 -Laplacian. 2013 Summary: Some theorems of existence of weak solutions are obtained for math3 -Laplacian equations with Dirichlet boundary conditions by using a critical point theorem.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 35Q51 35C08 46E35 Novikov; peakon solutions; integrable; Sobolev spaces; initial value problem; non-uniform dependence on initial data serial article Grayshan, Katelyn Number: 6109977 Peakon solutions of the Novikov equation and properties of the data-to-solution map. 2013 Summary: We consider both the periodic and the non-periodic Cauchy problem for the Novikov equation and discuss continuity results for the data-to-solution map in Sobolev spaces. In particular, we show that the data-to-solution map is not (globally) uniformly continuous in Sobolev spaces with exponent less than 3/2. To accomplish this, we construct sequences of peakon solutions whose distance initially goes to zero but later becomes large.

math.1: <m:math xmlns="http://zentralblatt.org" alttext="Q" xml:id="m1.1" display="inline" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:semantics xml:id="m1.1a" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:mi xml:id="m1.1.1" xref="m1.1.1.cmml">Q</m:mi><m:annotation-xml xml:id="m1.1.cmml" encoding="MathML-Content" xref="m1.1"><m:ci xml:id="m1.1.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.1">Q</m:ci></m:annotation-xml><m:annotation xml:id="m1.1b" encoding="application/x-tex" xref="m1.1.cmml">Q</m:annotation></m:semantics></m:math>

math.3: <m:math xmlns="http://zentralblatt.org" alttext="T^{{\ast}}" xml:id="m3.1" display="inline" xref="m3.1.cmml"><m:semantics xml:id="m3.1a" xref="m3.1.cmml"><m:msup xml:id="m3.1.3" xref="m3.1.3.cmml"><m:mi xml:id="m3.1.1" xref="m3.1.1.cmml">T</m:mi><m:mo xml:id="m3.1.2.1" xref="m3.1.2.1.cmml">‚àó</m:mo></m:msup><m:annotation-xml xml:id="m3.1.cmml" encoding="MathML-Content" xref="m3.1"><m:apply xml:id="m3.1.3.cmml" xref="m3.1.3"><m:csymbol cd="ambiguous" xml:id="m3.1.3.1.cmml">superscript</m:csymbol><m:ci xml:id="m3.1.1.cmml" xref="m3.1.1">T</m:ci><m:ci xml:id="m3.1.2.1.cmml" xref="m3.1.2.1">normal-‚àó</m:ci></m:apply></m:annotation-xml><m:annotation xml:id="m3.1b" encoding="application/x-tex" xref="m3.1.cmml">T^{{\ast}}</m:annotation></m:semantics></m:math>

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 76 liquid crystals; defects serial article Lamy, Xavier Number: 6109984 Some properties of the nematic radial hedgehog in the Landau-de Gennes theory. 2013 Summary: We consider, in the Landau-de Gennes theoretical framework of a math1 -tensor description of nematic liquid crystals, a radial hedgehog defect with strong anchoring conditions in a ball math2 . We show that the scalar order parameter is monotonic, and we prove uniqueness of the minimizing hedgehog below the spinodal temperature math3 .

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 91 fuzzy option pricing; call option; binary option; asset-or-nothing option serial article Thavaneswaran, A.; Appadoo, S.S.; Frank, J. Number: 6106998 Binary option pricing using fuzzy numbers. 2013 Summary: A binary option is a type of option where the payout is either fixed after the underlying stock exceeds the predetermined threshold (or strike price) or is nothing at all. Traditional option pricing models determine the option‚Äôs expected return without taking into account the uncertainty associated with the underlying asset price at maturity. Fuzzy set theory can be used to explicitly account for such uncertainty. Here we use fuzzy set theory to price binary options. Specifically, we study binary options by fuzzifying the maturity value of the stock price using trapezoidal, parabolic and adaptive fuzzy numbers.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 68T45 94A17 94A08 68U10 visual information; nuisance; communication theory book article Soatto, Stefano Number: 1251.68271 Actionable information in vision. 2013 Summary: A notion of visual information is introduced as the complexity not of the raw images, but of the images after the effects of nuisance factors such as viewpoint and illumination are discounted. It is rooted in ideas of J. J. Gibson, and stands in contrast to traditional information as entropy or coding length of the data regardless of its use, and regardless of the nuisance factors affecting it. The non-invertibility of nuisances such as occlusion and quantization induces an ‚Äúinformation gap‚Äù that can only be bridged by controlling the data acquisition process. Measuring visual information entails early vision operations, tailored to the structure of the nuisances so as to be ‚Äúlossless‚Äù with respect to visual decision and control tasks (as opposed to data transmission and storage tasks implicit in communication theory). The definition of visual information suggests desirable properties that a visual representation should possess to best accomplish vision-based decision and control tasks.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 46 local multiplier algebra; injective envelope; continuous trace math1 -algebra; continuous Hilbert bundle; weakly continuous Hilbert bundle serial article Argerami, Mart√≠n; Farenick, Douglas; Massey, Pedro Number: 6110004 Second-order local multiplier algebras of continuous trace math2 -algebras. 2013 Summary: We determine the injective envelope and local multiplier algebra of a continuous trace math3 -algebra math4 that arises from a continuous Hilbert bundle over an arbitrary locally compact Hausdorff space. In addition, we show that the second-order local multiplier algebra math5 of any such algebra A is injective.
